           <dt>&#x226b; dala </dt>
           <dd><em>dala</em> n. (m. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a>) a piece torn or split off. fragment (cf. <em>a&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a</em>, <em>carma-</em>, <em>dvi-</em>, <em>ve&#x1e47;u-</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> v, 3, 22 ; vi, 5, 4 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a> iv, 44 (ifc. f. <em>&#x0101;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naish-">Naish-.</a> vii, 31 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'part', a degree <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;">VarB&#x1e5b;.</a> xvii, 4 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a half (cf. <em>adhara-</em>, <em>ahar-</em>, <em>dyu-</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> i, 7 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x016b;ryas">S&#x016b;ryas.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a hemistich </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'unfolding itself.' a small shoot, blade, petal, leaf (often ifc. in names of plants)' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cinnamon leaf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; unclean gold <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhpr">Bhpr.</a> v, 26, 2 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>utsedha</em>, <em>&#x25cb;dhavad-vastu</em>, <em>avadravya</em> (<em>apad&#x25cb;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;putra</em> (cf. BrahmavP.) or (cf. P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 6-3, 22), m. 'the son of a female slave', a low wretch or miscreant (as an abusive word often in the plays)</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-d&#x012b;vya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 42, 9) to cast, throw, esp. dice, i.e. play, gamble (<em>ak&#x1e63;ais</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 34, 13 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iii, 2260 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ak&#x1e63;&#x0101;n</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-4, 43), with (instr. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> ii, 2509), for (instr., ii, 2061 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; acc. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MaitrS">MaitrS.</a> i, 6, 11 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> v, 4, 4, 23 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; dat. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iv, 534 ; ii, 2468 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; gen. [<em>&#x015b;atasya</em>] <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 2-3, 58) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to lay a wager, bet with (<em>s&#x00e2;rdham</em>), upon (dat.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> i, 1192 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to play, sport, joke, trifle with (acc. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> v, 29) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to have free scope, spread, increase (cf. Pa&#x00f1;c. ii, 193, B. <em>vardhati</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to shine, be bright [Zd. <em>d&#x012b;v</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (?) Lit. <em>dyvas</em>] <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> iii, 20, 22 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to praise, rejoice, be drunk or mad </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to sleep </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to wish for </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to go <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a>: Caus. <em>devayati</em>, to cause to play (cf. Sch.) or to sport <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> iii, 20, 22: Desid. <em>didevi&#x1e63;ati</em> and <em>dudy&#x016b;&#x1e63;ati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 7-2, 49 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a>: Caus. of Desid. <em>dudy&#x016b;&#x1e63;ayati</em>, to incite to play <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a> v, 49: Intens. <em>dediviiti</em>, <em>dedyeti</em>, <em>dedeti</em> &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vop">Vop.</a> xx, 17</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; div 3</dt>
           <dd><em>d&#x00ed;v</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; dyu </dt>
           <dd><em>dy&#x00fa;</em> (nom. <em>dya&#x00fa;s</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; voc. <em>dy&#x00e1;us</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> vi, 51, 5 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> vi, 4, 3] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; acc. <em>dy&#x0101;&#x0341;m</em> <em>d&#x00ed;vam</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; instr. <em>div&#x0101;&#x0341;</em> or <em>d&#x012b;&#x0341;v&#x0101;</em> <em>see below</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; dat. <em>dive</em> [<em>dyave</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> i, 3934] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; abl. gen. <em>div&#x00e1;s</em> [rarely <em>dy&#x00f3;s</em> e.g. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> iv, 27, 3 ; i, 115, 5] <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p478-3"></a>[Page 478, Column 3]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; loc. <em>div&#x00ed;</em>, <em>dy&#x00e1;vi</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; du. <em>dy&#x0101;v&#x0101;</em> s.v. [<em>dy&#x00e1;vii</em> as voc. only iv, 56, 5] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pl. nom. <em>dy&#x0101;&#x0341;as</em> [<em>divas</em> only ix, 118, 11] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; acc. <em>dy&#x016b;&#x0341;n</em> [rare, <em>d&#x00ed;vas</em>, <em>div&#x00e1;s</em> e.g. i, 194, 2 ; iv, 3, 8] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; instr. <em>dy&#x00fa;bhis</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; native grammarians give as stems <em>div</em> and <em>dyo</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the latter is declined through all cases like <em>go</em>, but really does not occur except in forms mentioned above and in <em>dyo-salila</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> viii, 4658, while <em>div</em> and <em>dyu</em> regularly alternate before vow. and cons.), m. (rarely f.) in Ved., f. in later Skr. heaven, the sky (regarded in Ved. as rising in three tiers [<em>avama</em>, <em>madhyama</em>, <em>uttama</em> or <em>t&#x1e5b;t&#x012b;ya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> v, 60, 6 &amp;c.], and generally as the father (<em>dya&#x00fa;&#x1e63;</em> <em>pit&#x0101;&#x0341;</em>, while the earth is the mother [cf. <em>dy&#x0101;v&#x0101;-p&#x1e5b;thivii</em>], and Ushas the daughter), rarely as a goddess, daughter of Praj&#x0101;-pati <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> iii, 33 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a>i, 7, 4,) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. (rarely n.) day(esp. in pl. and in such forms as <em>d&#x00ed;v&#x0101;</em>, by day (cf. s.v.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>dy&#x00e1;vi-dyavi</em>, daily, every day </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x00e1;nu dy&#x016b;&#x0341;n</em>, day by day, daily </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>dy&#x00fa;bhis</em> and <em>&#x00fa;pa dy&#x00fa;bhis</em>, by day or in the course of days, a long time <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. brightness, sheen, glow (only <em>dy&#x00fa;bhis</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 53, 4 ; iii, 3, 2 &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>adik&#x1e63;at</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>adik&#x1e63;i</em>, <em>&#x00e1;di&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>d&#x00ed;&#x015b;e</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a>) to point out, show, exhibit <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a>viii, 82, 15 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to produce, bring forward (as a witness in a court of justice) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> viii </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to assign, grant, bestow upon (dat. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ii, 41, 17 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> xiv, 2, 13 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to order, command, bid (inf.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kir">Kir.</a> v, 28: Pass. <em>di&#x015b;yate</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c.: Caus. <em>de&#x015b;ayati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>ad&#x012b;di&#x015b;at</em>, to show, point out, assign <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to direct, order, command <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to order, command <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>: Pass. <em>dedi&#x015b;yate</em>, to show or approve one's self. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> [Cf. Z. <em>dis</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Gk. ? ; Lat. <em>d&#x012b;co</em>, [479, 3] <em>in-d&#x1e5b;care</em> &amp;c. ; Goth. <em>teihan</em> ; O. E. <em>t&#x00e9;on</em> (fr. <em>t&#x00ed;han</em>).]</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; dikkany&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kany&#x0101;</em> f. a quarter of the sky deified as a young virgin <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhart&#x1e5b;">Bhart&#x1e5b;.</a> iii, 93 (v. l. <em>k&#x0101;nt&#x0101;</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; dikkara </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kara</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>)n. youthful, juvenile (lit. making, i.e. changing quarter continually, restless) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. a youth <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>aru&#x1e47;a</em> (as making a quarter for the sun) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-v&#x0101;sin&#x012b;</em> f. a form of Devii <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;karika</em> mfn. (ifc.) = <em>-karin</em> and (at, once) = <em>-karik&#x0101;</em>, f. the mark of a bite or of a nail <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a> iv, 9 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. N. of a river, K&#x0101;IP</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; du&#x1e63;yanta </dt>
           <dd><em>du&#x1e63;yanta</em> m. (fr. <em>dus</em> + &#x221a;<em>so</em>? or p. of &#x221a;<em>du&#x1e63;</em>?, older form <em>du&#x1e25;-&#x1e63;anta</em>) N. of a prince of the lunar race (descendant of Puru, husband of &#x015a;akuntal&#x0101; and father of Bharata) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; du&#x1e63;vanta </dt>
           <dd><em>du&#x1e63;vanta</em> w&#x1e5b;. for <em>du&#x1e63;yanta</em> above</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; dus </dt>
           <dd><em>dus</em> ind. a prefix to nouns and rarely to verbs or adverbs (cf. P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 2-1, 6 ; 2, 18 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 2 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> ; iii, 3, 126 &amp;c.) implying evil, bad, difficult, hard <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p488-2"></a>[Page 488, Column 2]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; badly, hardly ; slight, inferior &amp;c. (opp. to <em>su</em>), often = Engl. <em>in-</em> or <em>un-</em> [cf.&#x221a;2. <em>du&#x1e63;</em> ; Zd. <em>dush-</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Gk. ? ; Goth. <em>tu&#x015b;-</em> ; O&#x1e24;.G. <em>&#x015b;ur</em>.]. It becomes <em>dur</em> (q.v.) before vowels and soft consonants </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>d&#x016b;</em> (q.v.) before <em>r</em> and sometimes before <em>d</em>, <em>dh</em>, <em>n</em>, which become <em>&#x1e0d;</em>, <em>&#x1e0d;h</em>, <em>&#x1e47;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; remains unchanged before <em>t</em>, <em>th</em> (in older language however <em>&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;</em>, <em>&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;h</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; becomes <em>du&#x1e63;</em> (q.v.), rarely <em>du&#x1e25;</em> before <em>k</em>, <em>kh</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>p</em>, <em>ph</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>du&#x015b;</em> (q.v.) before <em>c</em>, <em>ch</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>du&#x1e25;</em> (q.v.), rarely <em>du&#x015b;</em>, <em>du&#x1e63;</em>, <em>dus</em>, before <em>&#x015b;</em>, <em>&#x1e63;</em>, <em>s</em></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to dishonour or violate (a woman) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> viii, 364 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (astrol.) to cause evil or misfortune <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Var">Var.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to object, refute, disprove, blame <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to see with the mind, learn, understand <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to notice, care for, look into, try, examine <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;c">Pa&#x00f1;c.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to see by divine intuition, think or find out, compose, contrive (hymns, rites, &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> ii, 11: Pass. <em>d&#x1e5b;&#x015b;y&#x00e1;te</em> (ep. also <em>&#x25cb;ti</em>), aor. <em>ad&#x00e1;r&#x015b;i</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. to be seen, become visible, appear <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be shown or manifested, appear as (<em>iva</em>), prove <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c.: Caus.            <dd>&#x2022; cl. 2. P. 2. sg.            <dd>&#x2022; Subj. P. <em>dar&#x1e63;asi</em>, <em>d&#x00e1;r&#x1e63;at</em> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; Pot. <em>&#x25cb;&#x1e63;&#x012b;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Prec. <em>d&#x012b;ry&#x0101;t</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> 15177) to burst, break asunder, split open <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> (cf. above) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause to burst, tear, rend, divide <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a>: Pass. <em>d&#x012b;ryate</em> (<em>&#x25cb;ti</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>), p. <em>d&#x012b;ryam&#x0101;&#x1e47;a</em> and <em>d&#x012b;ryat</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>dadre</em> (cf. &#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r. xiv, 27, 2) to be split, break open, fall asunder, decay <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be dispersed or scattered (as an army) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be frightened or afraid (also <em>darati</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xix, 47: Caus. P. <em>darayati</em>, to split, tear, break open <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; P. &#x0100;. <em>d&#x0101;rayati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>adadarat</em> (cf. P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 7-4, 95) to tear asunder, divide by splitting or digging <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to scatter, disperse <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>: Intens. P. <em>d&#x00e1;rdarti</em> or <em>d&#x0101;&#x0341;darti</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Impv. 2. sg. <em>d&#x0101;d&#x1e5b;h&#x00ed;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Subj. 3. sg. <em>dardirat</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; impf. 2. 3. sg. <em>&#x00e1;dardar</em>, 3. pl. <em>adardirur</em> = Caus. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> [Cf. Gk. ? and ? ; Lith.            <dt>deva </dt>
           <dd><em>dev&#x00e1;</em> mf(<em>i</em>)n. (fr. 3. <em>div</em>) heavenly, divine (also said of terrestrial things of high excellence) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> (superl. m. <em>dev&#x00e1;-tama</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> iv, 22, 3 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; f. <em>devi-tam&#x0101;</em>, ii, 41, 16) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. (according to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 3-3, 120 <em>d&#x00e9;va</em>) a deity, god <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c.&amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (rarely applied to) evil demons <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> iii, 15, 5 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> iii, 5, 4, 1 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (pl. the gods as the heavenly or shining ones </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>v&#x00ed;&#x015b;ve dev&#x0101;&#x0341;s</em>, all the gods <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ii, 3, 4 &amp;c., or a partic. class of deities [see under <em>v&#x00ed;&#x015b;va</em>], often reckoned as 33, either 11 for each of the 3 worlds <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 139, 11 &amp;c. [cf. <em>tri-da&#x015b;a</em>], or 8 Vasus, 11 Rudras, and 12 &#x0100;dityas <em>to which the 2 &#x0101;&#x015b;vins must be added</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. also cf. Divy&#x00e2;v. 68 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with Jainas 4 classes, viz. <em>bhavan&#x00e2;dh&#x012b;7&#x015b;a</em>, <em>vyantara</em>, <em>jyoti&#x1e63;ka</em>, and <em>vaim&#x0101;nika</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>dev&#x0101;&#x0341;n&#x0101;m p&#x00e1;tnyas</em>, the wives of the gods cf. RV. cf. VS. cf. Br. [cf. <em>deva-patn&#x012b;</em> below]) <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p492-3"></a>[Page 492, Column 3]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the number 33 ( above) cf. Ga&#x1e47;it </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of Indra as the god of the sky and giver of rain cf. MBh. cf. R. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a cloud cf. L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with Jainas) the 22nd Arhat of the future Ut-sarpi&#x1e47;&#x012b; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the image of a god, an idol cf. Vish&#x1e47; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a god on earth or among men, either Br&#x0101;hman, priest cf. RV. cf. AV. (cf. <em>bh&#x016b;-d&#x25cb;</em>), or king, prince (as a title of honour, esp. in the voc. 'your majesty' or 'your honour' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also ifc., e.g. <em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;-har&#x1e63;a-d&#x25cb;</em>, <em>vikram&#x00e2;&#x1e45;ka-d&#x25cb;</em>, king &#x015a;r&#x012b;-h&#x1e6d;harsha or Vikr&#x1e6d;Vikram&#x00e2;&#x1e45;ka, and in names as <em>puru&#x1e63;&#x00f4;ttama-d&#x25cb;</em> [lit. having Vish&#x1e47;u as one's deity </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>atithi-d&#x25cb;</em>, <em>&#x0101;c&#x0101;rya-d&#x25cb;</em>, <em>pit&#x1e5b;-d&#x25cb;</em>, <em>m&#x0101;t&#x1e5b;-d&#x25cb;</em>] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; rarely preceding the name, e.g. <em>deva-ca&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;amah&#x0101;sena</em> cf. Kath&#x0101;s. xiii, 48) cf. K&#x0101;v. cf. Pa&#x00f1;c. &amp;c. (cf. <em>k&#x1e63;iti-</em>, <em>nara-</em>, &amp;c.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a husband's brother (cf. <em>dev&#x1e5b;</em> and <em>devara</em>) cf. W </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a fool, dolt cf. L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a child cf. L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a man following any partic. line or business cf. L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a spearman, lancer cf. L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; emulation, wish to excel or overcome cf. L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sport, play cf. L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a sword cf. Gal </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of men cf. VP </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a disciple of N&#x0101;g&#x00e2;rjuna cf. MWB. 192 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; dimin. for <em>devadatta</em> cf. P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 5-3, 83 cf. V&#x0101;rtt.4 cf. Sch </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (n. cf. L.) an organ of sense cf. Mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;Up. iii, 1, 8 ; 2, 7 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. Hibiscus Mutabilis or Marsilia Quadrifolia ; (<em>&#x012b;&#x0341;</em>), f. s.v. [Cf. Lat. <em>d&#x012b;vus</em>, <em>deus</em> ; Lit. <em>de14vas</em> ; Old Pruss. <em>deiwas</em>.]</dd>

           <dt>do&#x1e63;a 2</dt>
           <dd><em>do&#x1e63;a</em> m. rarely n. (&#x221a;<em>du&#x1e63;</em>) fault, vice, deficiency, want, inconvenience, disadvantage <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c. <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p498-3"></a>[Page 498, Column 3]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; badness, wickedness, sinfulness <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; offence, transgression, guilt, crime (acc. with &#x221a;<em>&#x1e5b;</em> or <em>labh</em>, to incur guilt), SrS. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; damage, harm, bad consequence, detrimental effect (<em>nais9ha do&#x1e63;a&#x1e25;</em>, there is no harm </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ko'tra d&#x25cb;</em>, what does it matter?) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; accusation, reproach (<em>&#x25cb;&#x1e63;a&#x1e43;&#x221a;k&#x1e5b;</em> or <em>&#x25cb;&#x1e63;e&#x1e47;a-&#x221a;gam</em> with acc., to accuse) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; alteration, affection, morbid element, disease (esp. of the 3 humours of the body, viz. <em>pitta</em>, <em>v&#x0101;yu</em>, and <em>&#x015b;le&#x1e63;man</em>, 1 [cf. <em>trido&#x1e63;a</em> and <em>dh&#x0101;tu</em>], applied also to the humours themselves) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (also <em>&#x25cb;&#x1e63;aka</em>) a calf <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>dyut</em> cl. 1. &#x0100;. <em>dy&#x00f3;tate</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> (also <em>&#x25cb;ti</em>) &amp;c.            <dd>&#x2022; <em>-dyutya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a>) to shine, be bright or brilliant: Caus. <em>dyotayati</em> (<em>&#x25cb;te</em>, Bhs&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.) to make bright, illuminate, irradiate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; dravya </dt>
           <dd><em>dravya</em> n. a substance, thing, object <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (phil.) elementary substance (9 in the Ny&#x0101;ya, viz' <em>p&#x1e5b;thivii</em>, <em>ap</em>, <em>tejas</em>, <em>v&#x0101;yu</em>, <em>&#x0101;k&#x0101;&#x015b;a k&#x0101;la</em>, <em>di&#x015b;</em>, <em>&#x0101;tman</em>, <em>manas</em> ; 6 with Jainas, viz. <em>j&#x012b;va</em>, <em>dharma</em>, <em>adharma</em>, <em>pudgala</em>, <em>k&#x0101;la</em>, <em>&#x0101;k&#x0101;&#x015b;a</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (Gr.) single object or person, individual (cf. <em>eka-</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fit object or person (cf. <em>&#x0101;-</em>.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; object of possession, wealth, goods, money <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; gold <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> vii, 18, 34 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> </dd>
